description.definition: Relaxation techniques help reduce stress by calming your body and mind. These may include deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and visualization.
description.evidence: Studies show that regular relaxation practices reduce anxiety, improve sleep, and enhance academic performance (Smith et al., 2021).
steps: Find a quiet and comfortable place to sit.
Close your eyes and take a deep breath in through your nose.
Hold the breath for 3–5 seconds.
Exhale slowly through your mouth.
Repeat this for 5–10 minutes daily.
description.example: Before her exams, Amina spends 5 minutes deep breathing behind the classroom to stay calm.

description.definition: Mindfulness is focusing your full attention on the present moment without judging your thoughts or feelings.
description.evidence: Mindfulness training has been linked to reduced stress and better concentration among students (Kabat-Zinn, 2013).
steps: Sit comfortably and close your eyes.
Pay attention to your breathing.
When your mind wanders, gently bring it back to your breath.
Try to do this for 5 minutes every morning.
description.example: James uses mindfulness before class presentations to feel focused and confident.

description.definition: Having a positive attitude means choosing to focus on the good in situations and believing in your ability to overcome challenges.
description.evidence: Positive thinking is associated with lower stress levels and better emotional health (APA, 2020).
steps: Start your day with a positive affirmation.
Replace negative thoughts with hopeful ones.
Surround yourself with encouraging people.
Celebrate small achievements daily.
description.example: Even after failing a test, Rose told herself, 'I’ll do better next time' and studied with a friend.

description.definition: Sleep hygiene means following good habits that help you sleep well each night.
description.evidence: Good sleep improves memory, mood, and academic performance (CDC, 2022).
steps: Go to bed and wake up at the same time every day.
Avoid screens (phones/TV) 30 minutes before bed.
Make your sleeping area quiet and dark.
Avoid caffeine in the evening.
description.example: John stops using his phone at 9:00 PM and sleeps by 10:00 to wake up fresh for school.

description.definition: Exercise is any physical activity that gets your body moving, like walking, dancing, or playing sports.
description.evidence: Regular exercise reduces depression and anxiety, and boosts self-esteem (WHO, 2021).
steps: Choose an activity you enjoy (walking, dancing, sports).
Do it for at least 30 minutes most days.
Make it fun – invite a friend or play music.
Stretch before and after to avoid injury.
description.example: Fiona jogs every evening with her friend to clear her mind and feel better.

description.definition: Building healthy relationships means forming supportive connections with friends, family, and mentors.
description.evidence: Strong social support reduces stress and improves well-being among students (Mental Health Foundation, 2020).
steps: Spend time with positive people.
Be a good listener and show empathy.
Resolve conflicts respectfully.
Ask for help when you need it.
description.example: Maria talks to her sister when she feels overwhelmed with school work.

description.definition: Seeking help means reaching out to someone you trust — like a teacher, counselor, or friend — when you’re struggling.
description.evidence: Early help-seeking improves mental health outcomes and prevents problems from worsening (WHO, 2022).
steps: Recognize when you're feeling overwhelmed.
Think of someone you trust.
Share your feelings honestly.
Accept support and suggestions.
Follow up if you need more help.
description.example: When he felt too anxious to attend school, Peter spoke to his teacher who connected him with the counselor.

description.definition: Group therapy is a form of psychotherapy where a small group of individuals meet regularly under the guidance of a trained therapist to share experiences, offer support, and work through challenges together.
description.evidence: Research shows that group therapy can be as effective as individual therapy for many mental health conditions. It helps reduce feelings of isolation and builds social support (APA, 2021).
steps: Join a group led by a qualified therapist.
Agree on confidentiality and group rules.
Participate by sharing and listening actively.
Support others and receive support in return.
Reflect on feedback and apply insights to daily life.
description.example: A group of teens meets weekly to discuss anxiety and stress management strategies. By sharing openly and supporting each other, members feel less alone and more empowered to cope.
